text: as a security practitioner it's a very
rare opportunity to be able to talk
directly to developers in a conference
like the goto conferences and this is a
great opportunity for me to present the
work that I've been doing on threat
modeling threat modeling is the analysis
of systems for issues with security and
privacy and it's a process that has
traditionally been considered to be very
Happ heavy and very oriented to the
security team to the security
practitioner and something that
developers themselves uh normally would
not engage in as part of their
day-to-day
work the things that I brought to my to
my talk are a methodology for uh agile
threat modeling called continuous threat
modeling that developers can incorporate
into their workflows and in the way that
they uh do their work every day I
basically refer to it test threat model
every story and together with it but
working independently from the
methodology a tool that can be used to
do basic threat modeling uh that uses
python syntax to describe a system to uh
describe the data flows inside that
system and to elicit the what we call
the low hanging fruit the the basic
threats that that system could be under
and
uh I think that there is something for
everybody in there for the manager for
the developer for people who want to
understand how to put uh security into
their design into their implementation
from the beginning and uh during agile
workflows and uh incorporate this
practice into what should be your
security practice come to the talk take
a look listen to what I have and
hopefully there's going to be something
useful for
you
